page.title: 01Tempsford, Bedfordshire
page.content: Tempsford at the time of the first Domesday survey was measured as five hides,two virgates.Most of the land had been owned by William de Carun.In 1120 the ownership of Tempsford Manor which formed part of the Barony of Eaton was granted to the Beauchamps of Eaton. Today (1986) Tempsford is a small parish on the Huntingdon border.It has an area of some 2340 acres of which 1,060 are arable land 1010 permanent grass,and 35 woodlands.The ground is uniformly level,the N.W. boundry of the parish which is liable to floods being formed by the River Ouse.The soil is sand and clay.The chief crops produced are wheat ,barley peas and beans. Population records over the last century reveal a stable village population of approx 400.
